title-group.article-title: Physically based volumetric efficiency model for diesel engines utilizing variable intake valve actuation

contrib-group.aff: Ray W. Herrick Laboratories, Purdue University, West Lafayette, Indiana, USA

author-notes.corresp: *Ray W. Herrick Laboratories, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, USA. email: kocherl@purdue.edu

abstract.p: Advanced diesel engine architectures employing flexible valve trains enable emissions reductions and fuel economy improvements. Flexibility in the valve train allows engine designers to optimize the gas exchange process in a manner similar to how common rail fuel injection systems enable optimization of the fuel injection process. Modulating valve timings directly impacts the volumetric efficiency of the engine since it directly controls how much mass is trapped in the cylinders. In fact, it will be shown that the control authority of valve timing modulation over volumetric efficiency, that is, the range of volumetric efficiencies achievable due to modulation of the valve timing, is three times larger than the range achievable by modulation of other engine actuators such as the exhaust gas recirculation valve or the variable geometry turbocharger. Traditional empirical or regression-based models for volumetric efficiency, while suitable for conventional valve trains, are therefore challenged by flexible valve trains. The added complexity and additional empirical data needed for wide valve timing ranges limit the usefulness of these methods. A simple physically based volumetric efficiency model was developed to address these challenges. The model captures the major physical processes occurring over the intake stroke, and is applicable to both conventional and flexible intake valve trains. The model inputs include temperature and pressure in both the intake and exhaust manifolds, intake and exhaust valve event timings, engine cylinder bore, stroke, connecting rod lengths, engine speed, and effective compression ratio. The model is physically based, requires no regression tuning parameters, is generalizable to other engine platforms, and has been experimentally validated using an advanced multi-cylinder diesel engine equipped with a fully flexible variable intake valve actuation system. Experimental data were collected over a wide range of the operating space of the engine and augmented with air handling actuator and intake valve timing sweeps to maximize the range of conditions used to thoroughly experimentally validate the model for a total of 286 operating conditions. The physically based volumetric efficiency model will be shown to predict the experimentally calculated volumetric efficiency to within 5 per cent for all cases with a root mean square error of less than 2.5 per cent for the entire dataset. The physical model developed differs from previous physical modelling work through the novel application of effective compression ratio, incorporation of no tuning parameters, and extensive validation on a unique engine test bed with fully flexible intake valve actuation.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Fundamental to the control of engines is the measurement or estimation of the fuel and charge air masses [1]. In modern diesel engines utilizing exhaust gas recirculation (EGR), the charge air mass includes the fresh air mass and the EGR mass. No direct measurement for charge mass is available on modern engines. Several approaches have been taken to estimate charge mass for engine control. The most popular approach is to employ the speed–density equation [2–6] using the conditions in the intake manifold and a volumetric efficiency term. Volumetric efficiency is defined by Taylor [3] as the ratio of the mass of charge inducted into the cylinder to the mass of the charge mixture that would occupy the displaced piston volume at the inlet density. The determination of volumetric efficiency is critical to accurate charge estimation since it directly influences the speed–density charge mass calculation [1, 6, 7].

Volumetric efficiency is commonly modelled empirically as a black-box function of a combination of engine speed, intake manifold pressure, intake manifold temperature, and exhaust manifold pressure. Examples of this approach are common and have worked well for years. In reference [4], a regression model for volumetric efficiency with six tuning parameters was developed for a naturally aspirated gasoline engine with a standard valve train. In reference [8], a load variable based upon the pressure ratio across the compressor is utilized for turbocharged engines. In reference [9], a two-dimensional (2D) lookup table for volumetric efficiency is employed with engine speed and intake manifold pressure as the inputs. The table is calibrated from experimental engine data. Guzzella and Onder [10] advocate the use of 2D lookup tables to quantify volumetric efficiency. In references [11] and [12], the volumetric efficiency is modelled as a function of engine speed, intake manifold pressure, and temperature. Usage of these types of models has also become prevalent in gas exchange simulation models such as those described by Kocher et al. [13], Stefanopoulou et al. [14], and Jankovic et al. [15] which aim to utilize physical relationships to describe the gas exchange process but have stopped short of incorporating physically based volumetric efficiency models. In reference [16], the volumetric efficiency for the simulation is modelled by the use of three 2D lookup tables to act upon cylinder volume terms at intake valve closing and exhaust valve closing to describe the complicated relationship for variable valve timings. Neural networks, such as a radial basis function (RBF) or a multi-layer perception (MLP), have also been used [17], but this approach is generally challenged by the large quantity of experimental data needed to train and validate the model. De Nicolao et al. [17] developed a fourth-order polynomial model for volumetric efficiency. In reference [18], Jankovic and Magner provide a polynomial model linear in manifold pressure where the polynomial models were of fourth order. Canova et al. [19] utilize results from Hendricks et al. [11] to estimate the product of volumetric efficiency with intake manifold pressure as a linear function of the intake manifold pressure.

Online estimation approaches for determining charge air mass can also include estimation of volumetric efficiency. In reference [9], a 2D lookup table for volumetric efficiency is corrected through the use of an observer. In reference [6], an input observer is used to determine charge air mass by estimating an unknown additive volumetric efficiency term. Other observer approaches directly estimate charge air mass without directly estimating volumetric efficiency. In references [12] and [20], the charge air mass is estimated by use of a Luenberger observer on the intake manifold filling dynamics. Charge air mass can also be estimated from in-cylinder pressure measurement as described by Desantes et al. [21].

Unfortunately, the incorporation of advanced air handling configurations and the use of flexible valve timings limit the potential use of the aforementioned empirical black-box models (e.g. regression fits), neural networks, and lookup tables. As the complexity of the gas exchange process increases owing to the increase in the number of actuators affecting the process, the amount of data collection necessary to calibrate the model increases, resulting in large numbers of experimental tests. Even then, the model is only calibrated for one engine platform and is not directly transferable to other engine platforms. In addition, as engine hardware choices evolve over the course of the development cycle, the model may need to be calibrated multiple times, resulting in redundancy of work and prolonged testing time.

In short, the importance of physical, generalizable models for volumetric efficiency will increase as flexible valve train engines become more readily available. For example, in reference [22], the authors develop a physics-based model for a camless gasoline engine and show experimental validation at operating conditions covering the air flow range of the engine. In reference [23], the authors develop a volumetric efficiency model for variable cam-phasing and variable valve lift applications and show validation against a detailed simulation model. However, while the efforts in references [22] and [23] represent major progress towards a purely physically based volumetric efficiency model, both of these efforts utilize regression parameters (9 in reference [22], 16 in reference [23]) to augment the physical relationships derived, and in reference [23], does not include direct experimental validation. In this effort, a purely physically based volumetric efficiency model is developed and extensively experimentally validated over 286 operating conditions on a multi-cylinder diesel engine equipped with flexible intake valve actuation. The model inputs include temperature and pressure in both the intake and exhaust manifolds, intake and exhaust valve event timings, bore, stroke, connecting rod length, engine speed, and the effective compression ratio (ECR). The model does not incorporate any regression parameters, and instead relies on the direct physical relationships for prediction accuracy.

sec.title: 2 Experimental Set-Up
sec.p: The system under observation in this study is a 2008 Cummins diesel engine outfitted with an electro-hydraulic variable valve actuation (VVA) system. The Cummins ISB engine is a 6.7 l, 350 horsepower, six-cylinder direct-injection diesel engine with a 17.3:1 static geometric compression ratio. As shown in Fig. 1, the engine is an in-line six configuration. The cylinder head is a four-valve design, including two intake and two exhaust valves per cylinder. The engine comes equipped with a third-generation Bosch common rail fuel injection system with multi-pulse injection capability and a cooled EGR loop. The engine also has a variable geometry turbocharger (VGT) to boost engine performance over the entire operating range as well as an electronic EGR valve to allow control of fresh charge and EGR flows delivered to the in-cylinder combustion process.

caption.p: Schematic of a modern diesel engine

sec.p: The fully flexible VVA system, manufactured by Team Corporation, is capable of modifying the intake valve opening, the peak intake valve lift, and the intake valve closing on a cylinder-independent, cycle-to-cycle basis. The basic schematic for the VVA system is shown in Fig. 2. The hydraulic power supply provides high-pressure hydraulic oil to an electronic servo valve. The servo valve control signal is generated within a program uploaded to a dSPACE data acquisition and control system, and sent to the servo valve through a power amplifier. The servo valve moves, shuttling high-pressure hydraulic oil to one side of the piston actuator. The actuator presses on the intake valve crosshead, a bridge that connects the intake valve pair. The intake valves move with the actuator. No rigid connection exists between the actuator and the valve crosshead. To ensure contact, the valve springs provide upward return force to maintain contact.

caption.p: Schematic of a VVA system

sec.p: The intake valve profiles are generated on-the-fly in dSPACE. This provides the opportunity to adjust the valve profile on a cylinder independent, cycle-to-cycle basis. The intake valve profiles have three key features that describe the valve lift shape:

Three example intake valve profiles shown in Fig. 3 have the same IVO and IVL but have different IVCs. The middle profile duplicates the nominal, stock camshaft, IVC timing on the production version of the engine. The IVC timing can be modulated to produce various ECRs – a measure of the amount of compression on the intake charge gas. The IVC timing can occur earlier or later than the nominal IVC timing as shown in Fig. 3 to produce different ECRs. Two major piston positions are shown in Fig. 3: top dead centre (TDC) and bottom dead centre (BDC). TDC position refers to the piston position when the volume in the cylinder is at a minimum and the piston height is at a maximum. BDC position refers to the piston position when the volume in the cylinder is at a maximum and the piston height is at a minimum. TDC and BDC are also shown in Fig. 4 relative to the intake and exhaust valve profiles. A closer view of the intake and exhaust valve profiles are shown in Fig. 5, which also illustrates the location of prominent valve profile features. By inspection of Fig. 5, note that the amount of valve overlap can be varied by modulation of the IVO timing.

caption.p: Intake valve profiles with IVC modulation
Piston position and valve lifts
Intake and exhaust valve lift profiles

sec.p: The multi-cylinder diesel engine with fully flexible intake valve actuation at Purdue University provides a platform to extensively, experimentally validate the physically based volumetric efficiency model, formulated in the following sections, across a wide operating range.

sec.title: 3 Data Acquisition
sec.p: The experimental engine data are acquired using a dSPACE system. The dSPACE system collects data from the engine electronic control module (ECM), such as the fuelling and timing commands as well as ECM sensor measurements. The ECM data are sampled at 100 Hz over the engine controller area network, CAN, via a DS4302 board. The dSPACE system also collects data from additional temperature, pressure, flow, and emissions measurements instrumented on the engine test bed. Fresh air mass flow rate is measured using a laminar flow element (LFE) device. The engine charge flow is calculated using the LFE fresh air flow measurement and the measured EGR fraction. Emission gas analysers are used to measure the composition of the exhaust gases as well as the concentration of CO2 in the intake manifold. Cambustion non-dispersive infra-red (NDIR) fast CO2 analysers were utilized during this testing. EGR fraction is computed using the intake and exhaust manifold CO2 measurements. A potential measurement issue arises since the EGR distribution in the intake manifold is not completely uniform. The intake manifold CO2 is sampled in three locations and averaged to provide the best measurement average of the true intake manifold CO2, as shown in Fig. 1.

sec.title: 4 Effective Compression Ratio
sec.p: During the compression process in a four-stroke engine, the piston travels from BDC to TDC. At BDC, the in-cylinder volume is at its maximum. In general, as shown in Figs 4 and 5, the intake valves are completely closed around 20° after BDC. The trapped charge mass is compressed as it is forced into the minimum volume, know as the clearance volume, at TDC. During this process, the temperature and pressure of the charge is increased such that upon fuel injection, the fuel vaporizes and combusts. The compression process can be modelled as a polytropic compression process as shown in equation (1), where k is the polytropic coefficient, assumed to be a constant 1.35 in this work.

The standard metric used to indicate the level of compression is the static geometric compression ratio (GCR), defined as the ratio of the volume of the combustion chamber when the piston is at BDC to the volume of the combustion chamber when the piston is at TDC. This relationship is reflected in equation (2). As already noted, the IVC timing typically occurs after BDC, hence the compression process begins after BDC. The amount of piston motion-induced compression results in an ECR. The dynamic nature of the gas exchange process can create conditions where the ECR is larger than GCR. This situation occurs as a result of the inertial effects of the incoming fresh charge gas flow

The simplest method to estimate ECR is to take a ratio of the volume at IVC to the volume at TDC as shown in equation (3). This method, referred to as geometric ECR (GECR), produces relatively accurate results suitable for initial system design, however higher accuracy is desirable for control and modelling efforts. A more accurate pressure-based method can be used to compute the ECR using the pressure–volume (P–V) diagram of the compression process [24, 25]. Figure 6 precisely illustrates the procedure. The compression process is linearly extrapolated in the logP–logV diagram. In logP–logV space, the slope of the compression line is the polytropic coefficient. A horizontal line is drawn across the plot at the average intake manifold pressure. At the point the intake manifold pressure line meets the extrapolated compression line, the volume can be referred to as the effective IVC volume. The ECR is taken as the ratio of this effective IVC volume to the cylinder volume at TDC as shown in equation (4). The compression ratio calculated using the actual volume at IVC, equation (3), is generally different than the pressure-based method, equation (4), since the former strategy ignores the impact of flow momentum on in-cylinder charge compression and the effects of the non-linear valve closing profile. The pressure-based method accuracy is more accurate since it takes into consideration the compression occurring owing to both piston motion-induced compression and fluid momentum [24]. The ECR is minimally influenced by heat transfer and charge blow-by past the piston rings, however these effects are minor compared to the main effects

caption.p: ECR for early IVC

sec.title: 5 Volumetric Efficiency Model Derivation
sec.p: The volumetric efficiency of a diesel engine is a measure of how effectively the engine is able to draw charge gas into the combustion chambers and then expel combustion products from the cylinders. Gas exchange into the cylinders is the result of a series of overlapping physical processes that occur during the time between when the intake valve opens (IVO, and when the intake valve closes (IVC). In the effort described here, these physical processes are identified and modelled using physical principles resulting in a physically based volumetric efficiency model.

In a manner similar to the approach taken by Turin et al. in reference [23], an energy balance applied over the intake valve operating range is utilized to capture the main physical processes governing the gas exchange process between the intake and exhaust manifolds and the cylinder. However, unlike reference [23], there will not be tuning parameters (there are 16 in reference [23]) and the model is experimentally validated against engine data (reference [23] was validated using a detailed engine simulation model). Six main processes were identified as follows.

list-item.p: Residual exhaust gas energy in cylinder at IVO; Er
Back-flow exhaust gas energy from exhaust manifold to cylinder, IVO to exhaust valve closing (EVC); Eb
Fresh charge gas energy from intake manifold to cylinder, TDC to IVC; Ec
Piston work energy done by cylinder gas, IVO to IVC; Ep
Heat transfer energy to cylinder gas, TDC to IVC; Eq
Cylinder gas energy at IVC; Eivc

sec.p: Summing the first five physical processes leads to the formation of the energy balance for the cylinder gas over the intake process from IVO to IVC. Shown in equation (5) is the energy balance for the cylinder gas at IVC expressed as the summation of the five main physical processes. Figure 7 provides a visual representation of the breakdown of where the in-cylinder gas mass originates and over what crank angle period the mass is inducted

caption.p: Cylinder gas make-up

sec.title: 5.1 Residual exhaust gas
sec.p: The intake process begins at IVO when the intake valve starts to open. At this point, residual exhaust gases from the previous combustion cycle occupy the cylinder. The mass of the residual gas in the cylinder may be found by applying the ideal gas law as shown in equation (6). In the case of positive valve overlap (PVO), the condition in which the intake valve opens before the exhaust valve closes, the assumption that the pressure and temperature in the cylinder are the same as the conditions in the exhaust manifold, Pem and Tem, is applied. The energy of the residual gas is found by assuming a constant specific heat and making the manifold conditions assumptions as shown in equation (7). Substituting the ideal gas law into the energy relationship yields the following equation (8). As would be expected from physical intuition, the amount of mass and energy of the residual exhaust gas increases with larger exhaust manifold pressures and larger cylinder volumes at IVO

In the case of negative valve overlap (NVO), the condition in which the exhaust valve closes before the intake valve opens, a slight modification is implemented to account for the expansion of the residual gases in the cylinder from EVC to IVO. Polytropic expansion is assumed as shown in equation (9), where kexh is taken to be 1.28 for the residual gas polytropic coefficient

sec.title: 5.2 Exhaust gas back-flow
sec.p: For the PVO case, after IVO but prior to EVC, some residual exhaust gas in the cylinder is expelled out through the valves into the manifolds and then re-inducted back into the cylinder along with additional exhaust gas from the exhaust manifold, referred to as exhaust gas back-flow. The energy associated with exhaust gas back-flow is found by applying the ideal gas law and constant specific heat assumptions as shown in equation (14) where m·b is the exhaust mass flowrate from the exhaust manifold back into the cylinder. The integrated exhaust back-flow energy from equation (19) is derived starting from the ideal gas rate equation in equation (15). Since the gas constant R and Tem are considered constant, those terms are pulled out of the derivative in equation (16). Rearranging equation (16) to isolate m·b·dt yields equation (17). Integrating equation (17) gives an analytical expression for the exhaust gas back-flow mass as shown in equation (18). Substituting equation (18) into equation (14) provides the expression for the exhaust gas back-flow energy shown in equation (19). The temperature of the exhaust gas back-flow was assumed to be the exhaust manifold temperature. The cylinder pressure at EVC is assumed to be the exhaust manifold pressure. As would be expected, equation (19) reflects the importance of valve overlap (i.e. the difference between IVO and EVC) on the exhaust gas back-flow as well as the pressure differential across the cylinder
For the NVO case, since the exhaust valve closes before the intake valve opens, there will be no exhaust gas back-flow.

sec.title: 5.3 Fresh charge gas
sec.p: Once the intake valve has opened, fresh charge gas is inducted into the cylinder. The fresh charge mass, mc, is approximated in the standard approach using the speed–density equation and the conditions in the intake manifold. Heywood [2] and Taylor [3] use the speed–density equation to define volumetric efficiency. The speed–density equation can be formulated as in reference [11] using the intake manifold pressure and temperature as shown in equation (16) where Vd represents the swept displacement of the cylinder. The constant specific heat assumption is applied as shown in equation (21) resulting in the fresh charge gas energy relationship shown in equation (22). The engine volumetric efficiency, ηvol, is defined in equation (20) and represents the ratio of the mass of charge inducted into the cylinder to the mass of charge mixture that would occupy the displaced piston volume at the inlet density. The fresh charge gas formulation depends on the intake manifold conditions as expected. Once expressions for Ep and Eq are defined in the next two sections, equation (5) can be solved for ηvol by substituting expressions for Ep, Eq, equation (9), equation (19), and equation (22) into equation (5)

sec.title: 5.4 Piston work
sec.p: As the piston travels during the period from IVO to IVC, the piston does work on the cylinder gas owing to the volume change. The piston work, often called P-dV work, is shown in equation (23) and can be approximated by assuming that the pressure in the cylinder is the intake manifold pressure (IMP). The volumes at IVO and IVC are utilized based on the limits of integration. The piston work energy formulation is shown in equation (24). The piston work formulation reflects the approximate pressure in the cylinder and the volume over which the work is applied. As expected, the piston work increases with larger assumed cylinder pressure, Pim, or with larger volume differences between IVCeff and IVO

sec.title: 5.5 Heat transfer
sec.p: During the time between IVO and IVC, heat from the cylinder walls is being transferred into the inducted fresh charge gas. The temperature of the inducted fresh charge gas is assumed to be equal to the intake manifold temperature, Tim. The temperature of the cylinder walls is assumed to be equal to the mean average of the coolant temperature, Tclt, and the exhaust manifold temperature, Tem. The basic heat transfer equation is applied as shown in equation (26), where h is the heat transfer coefficient. The heat transfer coefficient was calculated using Woschni’s correlation [2] as shown in equation (27). Woschni’s correlation uses the cylinder bore, B, as the characteristic length scale and w as the local average gas velocity in the cylinder. w is proportional to the mean piston speed, S¯p, as shown in equation (28). The S¯p calculation is shown in equation (29) where S is the cylinder stroke and N is the engine speed. The final version of the heat transfer coefficient used is represented in equation (31)

The integrated surface area (SA) is difficult to calculate. The average surface area can be approximated as explained in what follows. The approximation is based upon the surface area of a cylinder of height l and diameter equal to the engine bore. The average surface area is then multiplied by the time for the piston to travel the desired range. The cylinder height, l, is determined using the slider-crank geometry as shown in equation (32) as defined in Heywood [2]. The connecting rod length, C, and piston clearance height, lcl, are taken from the engine cylinder geometry. Cylinder heights are calculated at three conditions (i.e. IVO, EVC, IVC) and then summed to arrive at the combined cylinder height
Substitution of the results into equation (26) yields the expression shown in equation (38) where SA represents the surface area time term

As expected, the heat transfer term increases for a larger temperature difference between the cylinder walls, Twall and the incoming charge air temperature, Tim and with an increase in the surface area time term. The surface area approximation is conservative and slightly overestimates the surface area. A comparison of the numerically integrated surface area time, the integral expression from equation (26), compared to the cylinder approximation used in this model, equation (37), is illustrated in Fig. 8.

caption.p: Surface area time approximation comparison

sec.title: 5.6 Cylinder gas energy
sec.p: The five previously described processes culminate in the cylinder gas energy at IVC. The cylinder gas energy at IVC can be calculated in a similar manner to the residual gas energy by utilizing the ideal gas relationship as shown in equation (39). The pressure at IVC can be approximated using polytropic compression, the effective volume at IVC, and the intake manifold pressure as given in equation (41). This follows from the definition of ECR and is shown in Fig. 6. The resulting expression for the cylinder gas energy at IVC is shown in equation (40)

sec.title: 5.7 Volumetric efficiency model
sec.p: Each term in equation (5) is now defined via equations (9), (19), (22), (24), (38), and (41). Re-arranging equation (5) to isolate the fresh charge energy on the left, yields

Substituting equation (22) into equation (42) and rearranging leads to the expression shown in equation (43). This expression will be utilized as a simple physically based diesel engine volumetric efficiency model. The full expression for the PVO case with substitutions is shown in equation (44) following substitution of equations (9), (19), (24), and (38) into equation (43). Similarly, the full expression for the NVO case is shown in equation (45). Note that the physically based volumetric efficiency model described herein does not contain any tuning or regression parameters, and as such, is unlike other volumetric efficiency models (e.g. references [8, 11, 16, 17, 22, 23])

sec.title: 6 Experimental Validation
sec.p: Experimental validation data were collected from the aforementioned test bed over the engine operating range depicted in Fig. 9. No experimental data were collected at rated power since the Pim, Pem, and engine speed ranges of the torque curve operation were already captured in the experimental dataset. Figure 10 shows the range of model inputs covered in the entire experimental dataset. The ranges for Pim and Pem in the experimental engine data encompass the total operating range experienced by the engine under nominal conditions. IVC was swept over a 165 crank angle degree window, producing an ECR range from 12 to 18, to capture the spectrum of IVC timings achievable by prototype variable valve timing systems. The range included both earlier- and later-than nominal timing as shown in Fig. 3.

caption.p: Experimental data operating locations
Volumetric efficiency over model input ranges

sec.p: In order to validate the model, the broadest range of Pim and Pem are desired since they represent key inputs to the model. To achieve the maximum ranges for Pim and Pem in addition to the ranges achieved under nominal operating conditions, air handling sweeps were conducted at three operating conditions as shown in Fig. 11. Within an air handling sweep, the EGR valve and the VGT actuator positions are swept through their useful operating ranges to map their coupled responses into the EGR fraction and charge flow space. The locations of the EGR valve and VGT are illustrated in Fig. 1. An air handling sweep from the experimental dataset is shown in Fig. 12. This exercise produces extremes in Pim and Pem not seen during normal engine operation at those operating conditions. The pressure range differences are shown in Fig. 13.

caption.p: Engine operating conditions for air handling sweeps
Air handling sweep at 1850 r/min and 407 N m
Pressure ranges for air handling sweep at 1850 r/min and 407 N m

sec.p: The physically based volumetric efficiency model performed well over the air handling sweeps, as shown in Figs 14 to 16. Figure 14 shows the model performance at the Case 1, 2300 r/min and 522 N m, operating conditions. The ranges of Pim and Pem are shown in Fig. 14 to illustrate the extreme range of pressures exercised in both the model and experiment. The air handling sweeps consist of sweeps of EGR valve position at three constant VGT positions followed by VGT position sweeps at three constant EGR positions. The impact of the EGR and VGT sweeps are readily visible by examining Pim and Pem. Looking at the pressures, the first set of data is an EGR position sweep from fully closed to fully open at a fully open VGT position. As the EGR valve position opens, Pim and Pem decrease. Point 1 in Fig. 14 corresponds to a fully closed EGR valve position while point 4 corresponds to a fully open EGR valve position. The VGT position was fully open for points 1–4 in Fig. 14. The next EGR sweep, points 5–8, is at a more closed VGT position corresponding to half of the useable VGT position range. The pressures show a marked increase over this sweep compared to the fully open VGT position sweep but similar trends hold as in the fully open VGT case. The final EGR sweep, points 9–12, shows identical model results to the previous sweep. At the conclusion of the EGR sweeps, the EGR valve position was fixed at 5 per cent and the VGT position was swept from 0 per cent to 70 per cent. This corresponds to points 13–16 in Fig. 14. The VGT sweep was then repeated two more times for EGR valve positions of 15 per cent, points 17–20, and 100 per cent, points 21–24.

caption.p: Volumetric efficiency over AHS sweep at Case 1
Volumetric efficiency over AHS sweep at Case 2
Volumetric efficiency over AHS sweep at Case 3

sec.p: The physically based volumetric efficiency model adequately predicts the measured volumetric efficiency over the air handling sweep. The measured volumetric efficiency does occasionally show values and trends that are unexpected such as points 10 and 12. At point 10, the EGR valve is opened slightly from the fully closed position and the measured engine volumetric efficiency increases by almost 5 per cent. This is counter to the expected result of a slight increase in volumetric efficiency as predicted by the model and shown in the experimental data at point 11. The discrepancy at point 10 may be due to the inherent complexity of experimental volumetric efficiency determination. The measured volumetric efficiency is calculated using an experimentally measured EGR fraction which has some inherent error owing to the non-uniformity of the EGR distribution in the intake manifold. Under these conditions, the CO2 sampling ports are seeing local areas of concentration of CO2 that may not reflect the average distribution in the intake manifold resulting in an incorrect engine volumetric efficiency. Non-uniformity of EGR distribution is common on modern diesel engines owing to the design trade-off between EGR mixing and the pressure loss to support mixing. Beatrice et al. provide evidence of the importance of EGR uniformity to low-temperature combustion [26]. Partridge et al. detail the level of non-uniform mixing in a typical modern diesel engine in reference [27] and Lujan et al. provide a methodology that permits the identification of the cylinder-to-cylinder distribution of EGR in a commercial engine [28].

Figure 15 presents the model results for Case 2, 1850 r/min and 407 N m, operating condition. Similar trends are apparent in Fig. 15 as shown for Case 1 in Fig. 14. Figure 16 presents the model results for Case 3, 1000 r/min and 203 N m, operating condition. At this operating condition, the exhaust gas enthalpy is considerably lower as reflected by lower Pim and Pem. The air handling system does not have significant control authority at this condition resulting in minimal response of the system from the sweep on the air handling inputs.

As will be demonstrated in the following, the input with the largest control authority over volumetric efficiency is the IVC timing. The effect of IVC timing on volumetric efficiency has been shown previously by Modiyani et al. [25], Jankovic and Magner [18], Turin et al. [23], and Mahrous et al. [29] through detailed simulation and experimental results. In this experimental dataset, IVC timing sweeps were run at five different engine speeds to demonstrate the impact of IVC modulation-induced ECR variations on volumetric efficiency as shown in Figs 17 to 19. The IVC timing sweeps included both early and late IVC timings as shown in Fig. 3. Two different IVO timings were used at two different engine speeds to explore the impact that valve overlap has on volumetric efficiency as shown in Fig. 19. ECR has a strong direct relationship with volumetric efficiency, as demonstrated in Fig. 17. Specifically, ηvol increases monotonically with ECR. Note that from comparison of the ηvol subplots in Figs 14 to 19, the control authority over volumetric efficiency by IVC modulation is more than three times as large as that observed through modulation of Pim and Pem. Figures 14 to 16 show that the control authority of the EGR valve and the VGT is approximately 10 per cent, a range from 0.85 to 0.95 volumetric efficiency, while Figs 17 to 19 show that the control authority of IVC modulation is approximately 40 per cent, a range from 0.55 to 0.95 volumetric efficiency. Figure 21 demonstrates the direct effect of IVC on volumetric efficiency for all points in the dataset. In other words, for flexible valve trains, capturing the impact of IVC modulation on volumetric efficiency is a primary concern. Figures 18 and 19 demonstrate the physically based volumetric efficiency models ability to capture these effects.

caption.p: Volumetric efficiency over ECR range
Volumetric efficiency over ECR sweep
Volumetric efficiency over IVO and IVC sweep

sec.p: In Fig. 18 the IVO timing remained unchanged and only IVC timing was modulated. These data points correspond to the engine being run in an advanced combustion mode called pre-mixed charge compression ignition or PCCI. PCCI can be enabled via flexible valve trains [24]. PCCI typically requires the usage of high EGR fractions (in excess of 40 per cent) and early injection timings (30° before TDC). These operating conditions provide unique experimental data to validate the physically based volumetric efficiency model. The direct impact of IVC modulation on volumetric efficiency is clearly shown in Fig. 18 as three main IVC timings were run at three different engine speeds resulting in large changes in measured volumetric efficiency. Points 85–132 were collect at 1600 r/min, points 133–171 were collected at 2000 r/min and points 172–212 were collected at 1200 r/min. Figure 8 demonstrates the models ability to capture the impact of IVC modulation on volumetric efficiency across the speed range of the engine.

In Fig. 19 both IVO and IVC were modulated as shown. The engine was operated under nominal diesel combustion conditions at these points with EGR fractions between 10 per cent and 25 per cent to test the IVC modulation under non-PCCI conditions. Both early and late IVC conditions were examined. The engine speed was varied from 1000 r/min (points 213–236) to 1850 r/min (points 237–252). In both cases, the physically based volumetric efficiency model accurately captures the trends associated with the IVO and IVC changes. As expected, a decrease in ECR results in a decrease in volumetric efficiency as shown in Fig. 17. A decrease in valve overlap also results in a small decrease in volumetric efficiency.

Figure 20 illustrates the individual contribution of each energy term in the volumetric efficiency model for all points. The energy values are plotted in kJ for an individual cylinder. Figure 21 shows the engine calculated volumetric efficiency corresponding to the energy term data shown in Fig. 20.

caption.p: Volumetric efficiency model energy terms in kJ
Volumetric efficiency over all points

sec.p: Presented in Fig. 22 are the complete results of the physically based volumetric efficiency model, equations (44) and (45), compared to the volumetric efficiency calculated from the experimental engine data (using data from Figs 14 to 16, 18, and 19). The dashed lines in Fig. 22 represent ±5 per cent lines. As illustrated in Fig. 22, the physically based volumetric efficiency model accurately predicts the experimentally calculated engine volumetric efficiency to within 5 per cent for all cases. The r.m.s. (root mean square) error for the model is under 2.5 per cent. It is worthwhile to re-emphasize that the purely physically based volumetric efficiency model does not require any regression parameters or regression fits to achieve the accuracy demonstrated. The model is applicable to conventional valve trains (as demonstrated in Figs 14 to 16) as well as fully flexible intake valve train configurations (as demonstrated in Figs 14 to 16, 18, and 19), including those which allow modulation of IVO and IVC. The model is generalizable to other engine platforms, providing an estimate or measurement of ECR is available, since the model is based solely on manifold conditions, engine cylinder geometry, and known valve timings.

caption.p: Physically based volumetric efficiency model results

sec.title: 7 Conclusions
sec.p: Charge air mass estimation is critical to the precise and robust control of modern engines since no direct measurement of charge air mass is available. Charge air mass is calculated through the application of the speed–density equation using the conditions in the intake manifold and volumetric efficiency. This paper presents the derivation and extensive experimental validation of a simple physically based volumetric efficiency model for diesel engines utilizing flexible intake valve actuation. The model was derived utilizing an integrated energy balance approach applied over the intake process from IVO to IVC. The model does not rely on any regression tuning parameters and is purely analytical. The model is applicable to current technology engines as well as advanced engines with flexible intake valve actuation. The model is generalizable to other engine architectures utilizing alternative air handling configurations since the model utilizes the immediate boundary conditions around the cylinder, the pressure and temperature in the intake, and exhaust manifolds. This approach enables the model’s use on a cylinder-specific basis so long as an estimate or measurement of ECR is available on a cylinder-to-cylinder basis. This allows for different IVO, IVC, and EVC timings to be run for different cylinders while still estimating the cylinder specific volumetric efficiency. It also allows for multiple manifolds to be utilized. The model utilizes base engine sensors available on any modern diesel engine and an additional in-cylinder pressure measurement to calculate the ECR if no estimate is available. Experimental engine data was collected using a unique advanced multi-cylinder diesel engine equipped with a fully flexible variable intake valve actuation system. The experimental engine data was collected over a large portion of the engine operating map. The VVA system was used to modulate the IVC timing over a 165 crank angle degree window producing an ECR range from 12 to 18. Model results were compared with corresponding engine test data. The model sufficiently predicts calculated engine volumetric efficiency within 2.2 per cent RMS error.

ack.p: Special thanks go to Cummins, Inc. for providing the engine and other experimental equipment, as well as technical support, especially from the following researchers at the Cummins Technical Center in Columbus, Indiana: Ray Shute, Tim Frazier, Cheryl Klepser, Don Stanton, Phanindra Garimella, and Rajani Modiyani. Special thanks also go to AVL North America, Inc. for providing the use of an AVL 621 Indimodul for the collection and analysis of in-cylinder pressure transducer data. The authors also wish to thank the Technical Services staff at the Ray W. Herrick Laboratories for their assistance: Fritz Peacock, Bob Brown, Gil Gordon, and Frank Lee.
